The Louisiana Legislature left some 400 bills for Gov. Buddy Roemer when it adjourned last week. The remarkably harsh anti-abortion bill has attracted wide attention.
People with an eye for history will take a long look, also, at the lottery bill.

The State Constitution prohibits a lottery, and for good reason. An earlier lottery, established in 1869 by carpetbaggers for a New York gambling syndicate, was so corrupt that other states wanted it banned from using the mails.

In 1880 President Benjamin Harrison declared that ''the people of all the states are debauched and defrauded'' by Louisiana's game, and persuaded Congress to approve a postal ban. Eventually the lottery was shut down.

Now the state budget is $600 million in the red, and lottery promoters offer a quick fix. Because the question involves changing the Constitution, it must go to a popular referendum in the fall. Meanwhile the Governor must deal with a bill creating an agency to run it if the referendum carries.

Governor Roemer opposes a lottery as an unseen tax on the poor. But he says it's the voters' decision. He could help them decide by vetoing the bill on his desk; he would also set a good example for other politicians who succumb to the temptation of lotteries when they can't muster the courage to balance their budgets the old-fashioned way, by cutting spending or raising taxes.
